abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Industrial
            Restructuring Demonstration Project in Algeria is
            unsatisfactory. Most enterprises did not perform as
            envisaged. The Bank's identification, preparation and
            appraisal of the IRDP was deficient. It should be noted that
            the Bank underestimated the risks associated with the
            project, as well as the degree of difficulty of PE
            restructuring. The supervision of the project was deficient.
            One annual supervision mission was not enough to allow
            proper follow up or the opportunity to identify and solve
            major problems. The Borrower's performance was
            deficient and its commitment to the project and its
            objectives was unsatisfactory. Key lessons learned include:
            Borrower ownership must be sought throughout the project,
            from conception to completion. (1) The lack of commitment of
            the stakeholders to this project resulted in poor enterprise
            performances; (2) micro-level restructuring without an
            enabling macroeconomic framework is unlikely to be
            successful; (3)ownership restructuring should be an
            essential component of an industrial restructuring project;
            (4) project objectives, as well as their implications, need
            to be stated with clarity, (5) consistency and transparency
            so that participating enterprises know precisely what is
            required of them; (6) an efficient and close supervision as
            well as dialogue should be maintained, on a continuous
            basis, with the Borrowers; (7) project implementation units
            must be familiarized with Bank guidelines so that an
            efficient organizational structure is maintained during implementation.
